content.title: an interesting result on divergence of Taylor expansion for dropout
content.review:
The second order approximation technique, introduced by Bishop (1995), was recently used to compare the dropout trained logistic regression model with standard regularizers. The author argued that this approximation does not work for logistic regression models with negative log loss  trained with dropout noise injection, since it is based on a divergent Taylor approximation  in this setting.  Therefore, the subsequent dropout analysis based on this approximation remains ill-founded to date. The results seem interesting.

minor comments:
(1) there are two == in eq (1)
(2) page 3, "this the Taylor series" should be "this Taylor series"
content.confidence: 3: The reviewer is fairly confident that the evaluation is correct

content.title: dropped everything
content.review:
Looking at Theorem 2 makes me conclude that the paper must be wrong because it does not depend on the dimension of the data. When there is only 1 dimension, the second order approximation is bad. When there are many dimensions where x has similarly magnitude in each dimension then the score resulting from dropout converges to a Gaussian.

A major mistake is in the display mode equation between 2 and 3.  Stating that the variance of the dropout score is proportional to the square of the linear score (beta x). This is wrong because the decision to dropout each coordinate is independent. The actual variance is much smaller (only \Var(\beta \cdot (\xi \odot x)) = \sum_j Var(\beta_j x_j \xi_j)), because the r.v. is a sum of many independent r.v.
content.confidence: 5: The reviewer is absolutely certain that the evaluation is correct and very familiar with the relevant literature

content.title: Divergence of Taylor series for logistic regression
content.review: The authors show that the Taylor series expansion used to model dropout is likely to be divergent for logistic regression models.  If I understand correctly, the authors seem to imply that if the Taylor series expansion is not bounded, the approximation could be arbitrarily poor - hence the analysis of drop being equivalent to a first order Taylor series expansion is difficult to justify?  The result seems interesting, but not being familiar with the related work, I'm not certain as to how prevalent this characterization of dropout is in the literature.
content.confidence: 2: The reviewer is willing to defend the evaluation, but it is quite likely that the reviewer did not understand central parts of the paper

content.title: ICLR 2018 Workshop Acceptance Decision
content.comment: Based on the reviews, this paper has not been accepted for presentation at the ICLR workshop. However, the conversation and updates can continue to appear here on OpenReview.
